Fig 1 Fig. 2 N2 adsorption-adsorption isotherms (a); the corresponding pore size distribution curves (b); XRD patterns (c) and FT-IR spectra (d) of the samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of CN, CNHU, CNHU/AC5 and AC: (a) C 1 s, (b) N 1 s, and (c) O 1 s. In this paper, we developed a one-dimensional activated carbon (AC) coated graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) hybrid nanorods (CNHU/AC) synthesized via an ultrasonic-hydrothermal method. The dual modulation of ultrasonic cavitation and hydrothermal confinement enables simultaneous morphology engineering (1D nanorod formation) and inerfacial microstructure optimization, endowing CNHU/AC with exceptional photoelectron transfer properties. Comparative studies with pristine g-C3N4 and hydrothermally modified CNHU without AC addition reveal that the optimal AC loading (CNHU/AC5) achieves remarkable Cr(VI) photoreduction under visible light, exhibiting rate constants 6.6 times and 2.1 times higher than those of g-C3N4 and CNHU, respectively. This enhancement originates from synergistic effects: (1) AC’s photosensitization broadens light absorption while its coating establishes intimate interfacial contact for accelerated charge transfer; (2) The 1D architecture directs axial elctron transport, coupled with surface C = O/O = C OH groups acting as electron traps; (3) Citric acid functions as both hole scavenger and Cr(VI) complexation agent to lower reduction barriers. This study establishes a paradigm for designing carbon-coupled heterostructures for the sustainable heavy metal remediation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Activated carbon Graphitic carbon nitride Work-function-tailored Visible light photocatalysis Cr(VI) reduction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cr(VI) is considered as one of the most hazardous contaminants in surface and ground water due to its toxicity, carcinogenicity and mutagenicity [1]. Cr (VI) is extremely harmful to human health, long term exposure can result in allergic reaction, skin ulcers, tympanic membrane rupture and even cance [2]. Conventional remediation techniques including chemical precipitation, electrochemical process, adsorption, ion exchange, and membrane technology often suffer from significant limitations such as high operational costs, secondary waste generation, or incomplete detoxification [3,4]. Photocatalytic reduction has emerged as a promising alternative that simultaneously addresses environmental remediation and solar energy utilization [5–8]. This approach enables redox reactions under ambient conditions using semiconductor catalysts, offering a sustainable pathway for pollutant degradation [9–12]. Among various photocatalysts, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has attracted considerable interest as a metal-free, visible-light-responsive semiconductor due to its excellent physicochemical stability, suitable band gap and nontoxicity [13]. Nevertheless, the practical application of pristine g-C3N4 remains constrained by the rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and low utilization of visible light [14]. Additionally, its layered structure makes it difficult for Cr(VI) to make adequate contact with electrons on the surface of the photocatalyst [15]. Strategically enhancing charge separation efficiency and modulating interfacial redox kinetics is essential for improving the photocatalytic performance of semiconductor materials [9,16–19]. Recent advances focus on combining g-C₃N₄ with functional carbon allotropes, leveraging their exceptional electrical conductivity, tailorable surface chemistry, and electron reservoir properties [20]. For instance, in the heterojunctions created with g-C3N4, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene can increase the reactant adsorption, and their high conductivity can promote the transmission of photogenerated electrons [21,22]. The photocatalytic effectiveness of C60 modified g-C3N4 composite is greatly increased under visible light due to the strong interaction of C60 and g-C3N4 conjugated-bond [23]. Carbon quantum dots (CQDs) can act as photosensitizers, injecting electrons into g-C3N4 under long-wavelength irradiation while concurrently prolonging carrier lifetime through trap-mediated transfer [24]. However, the complex synthetic routs and high costs limit their practical application. As a cost-effective carbon material with abundant surface functional groups and tunable porosity, activated carbon(AC) has emerged as a promising modifier for semiconductor photocatalysts. Recent advances demonstrate that AC/g-C3N4 hybrids exhibit enhanced photocatalytic performance through improved charge separation and light absorption [25,26]. However, conventional preparation methods involving thermal polymerization of nitrogen-rich precursors with carbon metrials suffer from uncontrollable precursor sublimation and insufficient interfacial contact, often yielding bulk composites with limited active sites [27,28]. Additionally, the precise role of AC in interfacial charge dynamics remains ambiguous - whether it primarily functions as an electron reservoir, photosensitizer, or structural promoter requires systematic clarification [29,30]. Moreover, the electron transfer pathways at g-C3N4/AC heterojunctions lack experimental validation, particularly regarding the influence of interfacial chemical bonding and energy band alignment. These limitations result in suboptimal utilization of AC's multifunctional advantages and hinder the development of high-performance photocatalytic systems for environmental remediation. In this paper, we developed a facile strategy for synthesizing active carbon modified g-C3N4 photocatalyst (CNHU/AC) with precisely engineered interfaces. AC was well coated on the surface of 1D g-C3N4 nanorods, forming a unique interfacial microstructure. In this case, the morphology, specific surface area and photoelectron characteristics of modified g-C3N4 are optimized by AC modification and morphology regulation. Through comparative experimental studies and density functional theory (DFT) simulations, we systematically elucidate the interfacial charge transfer mechanism. The results revealed that the C = O/O C = O groups at the heterointerface create electron-deficient regions that drive directional electron migration from g-C₃N₄ to AC. The unique interfacial microstructure enables CNHU/AC express remarkable Cr(VI) photoreduction, exhibiting a rate constant 6.6 times higher than that of pristine g-C3N4. Our work not only establishes a novel paradigm for constructing carbon-coupled photocatalytic systems but also provides atomic-level insights into the structure-activity relationships governing charge transfer in carbon-based heterojunctions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Active carbon was obtained from National Engineering Research Center for Flue Gas Desulfurization. Dicyandiamide, potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7, Kelong), diphenyl carbonyl hydrazine (Kelong), ethanol (Kelong), formic acid (Kelong), citric acid (Kelong), tartaric acid (Kelong), Tert-butanol (TBA, Aladdin), sodium persulfate (Na2S2O8, Aladdin), 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO, Aladdin),coumarin (Aladdin), 7-hydroxycoumarin(Aladdin), nitro blue tetrazolium(NBT, Aladdin), copper sulfate (CuSO4·5H2O, Kelong), l-ascorbic acid(Aladdin) and neocuproine(NP, Aladdin) were of analytic grade. The ultrapure water used throughout the study was provided by a Milli-Q system. 2.2 Preparation of photocatalysts The bulk g-C3N4 (labeled as CN) was obtained by the thermal polymerization method using dicyandiamide as starting material. The AC coated g-C3N4 composites were synthesized by a hydrothermal technique assistant with ultrasonic irradiation (Fig. S1). Firstly, g-C3N4 was dissolved in 20 mL pure water in polytetrafluoroethylene hydrothermal reactor. Then, a certain mass percent of AC was dispersed into the solution and keep it in ultrasonic state for 2 h. Next, placed the hydrothermal reactor in the vacuum drying oven and heated it for 4 h at 160 °C. After natural cooling, washed the product thoroughly with deionized water and heated it in the oven for 9 h at 80 °C. The synthesized g-C3N4/AC catalyst was named CNHU/ACx AC (x = 0.5, 2.5, 5 and 10) according to the mass percent of AC. For comparison, a control sample, denoted as CNHU, was prepared by the same procedures and at same conditions as those CNHU/ACx composites except the AC power was added. 2.3 Characterization Detailed characterizations were provided as Electronic Supporting Information (ESI) 2.4 Photocatalytic experiments The photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) over the as-prepared photocatalysts were conducted in a double walled quarts reactor upon visible light irradiation. The visible light was provided by the Xe lamp equipped with a UV cut off filter (λ>400 nm). Typically, 20 mg of the prepared samples were distributed in 150 mL of Cr(VI) solution (20 mg/L, pH=3) with steady stirring for 30 min in the dark to establish an adsorption-desorption equilibrium. The mixture was then irradiated with visible light for a photocatalytic experiment. After that, a particular amount of citric acid solution with a concentration of 3.5 mol/L was added into the above mixture as a hole scavenger. During the visible light irradiation, 4 mL of the suspensions was collected at different times. The concentration of Cr(VI) was determined using the diphenylcarbazide spectrophotometric method [31]. Total copper (TCu) concentrations were determined using a UV–vis spectrometer at 454 nm after it had been reduced into Cu(I) using l-ascorbic acid and chelated with NP. Cu(I) was determined at 454 nm after 1 mM NP had been added before reaction [32]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of catalysts The morphology and microstructure of CN, CNHU and CNHU/ACx are shown in Fig. 1 . According to Fig. 1a, bulk g-C3N4 has a typical block structure. During the hydrothermal with ultrasonic assistance, CNHU sample exhibits a one-dimensional nanorod structure with smooth surface (Fig. 1b). For CNHU/AC5, AC particles are coated on the surface of g-C3N4 whiles maintaining the 1D morphology but exhibits rougher surface (Fig. 1c). Furthter increasing the AC loading (CNHU/AC10) results in complete wapping of the g-C3N4 nanorods by AC (Fig. S2). Furthermore, the elemental mapping was used to further verify that the composition of AC and g-C3N4, and the elements of C, N, and O were dispersed on the sample surface (Fig. 2d). The above characterizations mutually confirm that AC was well coated on g-C3N4. Meanwhile, the formation of nanorod structure was further evidenced by HRTEM (Fig. 1f). The interface between AC and g-C3N4 can even be observed in Fig. 1 g The 1D nanostructure and interface contact between activated carbon and g-C3N4 would facilitates the migration of photogenerated electron-hole pairs to improve photocatalytic efficiency significantly [33,34]. We also find that the prepared materials have mesoporous structure with the pore size distribution in the range of 2∼30 nm (Fig. 2 a-b). The specific surface areas of CNHU/ACx increase with the increase of AC doping amount (Table S1). However, the total pore volume shows only marginal improvement, which can be attributed to the fact that excessive AC with micropore have filled part of the mesopores on the g-C3N4 nanorod surfaces The crystalline structures of the samples are presented by XRD patterns. As shown in Fig. 2c, two obvious peaks can be observed for CN, CNHU and CNHU/ACx samples, suggesting that they have the same crystal structure. No diffraction peaks of AC have been observed in CNHU/ACx composites. This evidence can be attributed to its amorphous state and high dispersion on the g-C3N4 surface, which is consistent with previous studies [35,36].The (002) diffraction peak intensity of CNHU decrease slightly demonstrates the reduction of g-C3N4 layered structural units [37]. While the weaker peak at (100) may be related to the breakdown of surface hydrogen bonds during the hydrothermal process [38]. The result indicates the samples fabricated by ultrasonic and hydrothermal method tend to be more intimate, which is consistent with the 1D nanorod structure. The hybrid sample of CNHU/ACx showed no significant peak shifts compared with pure CN, which indicated that there was obvious π-π interaction between CNHU and AC [39,40]. The FT-IR spectra shows that the chemical structure of CNHU and CNHU/ACx composites are similar to those of bulk g-C3N4 (Fig. 2d). The absorption peaks observed between 1200–1700 cm-1 correspond to the stretching vibration of CN and the characteristic respiratory mode of aromatic =CN heterocycles, whereas that at 813 cm-1 can be attributed to the specific respiratory pattern of the triazine unit. Moreover, the wide vibration band observed between 3000–3500 cm-1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of non-condensed terminal amino group (-NH2 or -NH groups) or hydroxyl group. Similarly, no absorption peak of AC has been observed in the FT-IR spectra of CNHU/ACx, which is consistent with the results of XRD. We compared the XPS spectra of CN, CNHU, CNHU/AC5, and the commercial AC, as shown in Fig. 3 . The XPS survey spectra (Fig. S3) demonstrates that CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 are consist of C, N and O, and the commercial AC is C and O. Fig. 3a shows the C 1 s XPS spectra of the samples. For CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 samples, the peaks at 288.34, 286.40 and 284.80 eV are assigned to the carbons in N‒C = N bond formed by sp2 hybrid carbon, C‒OH and C‒C bond, respectively [41,42]. The C 1 s spectra for AC is deconvoluted into four peaks with binding energies of 289.66, 288.32, 286.26 and 284.82 eV, respectively corresponding to the carboxyl carbon (O‒C = O), carbonyl carbon (C = O), carbon bound to a hydroxyl group (C‒OH) and skeleton carbon (C‒C) [43–45].This finding indicates that AC has rich oxygen-containing functional groups [36]. The surface areas of C‒C (27.3 %, 284.80 eV) and –C‒OH (3.0 %, 286.4 eV) are higher in CNHU/AC5 than those in CN and CNHU, which marks the successful deposition of AC on the surface of g-C3N4 (Tab. S3). N 1 s spectra is deconvoluted into three peaks at 401.1, 399.6 and 398.7 eV, corresponding to the N in ‒NH2 or =NH groups, N in N‒(C)3 bond between 3-s-triazine ring structural units and sp2 hybridization of N atoms in C‒N = C (Fig. 3b) [46,47]. In Fig. 3c, the O 1 s signals for AC could be deconvoluted into three peaks at 534.2, 532.28 and 530.66 eV, corresponding to the oxygen in the absorbed moisture, hydroxyl oxygen (‒OH) and carbonyl oxygen (C = O) [48]. However, there is only one peak in the spectra of O 1 s for CN at 532.54 eV, which is assigned to oxygen in N‒C‒O bond. For CNHU, obviously, there are two peaks. The one at 533.24 eV could be attributed to oxygen in ‒OH bond and the one at 531.69 eV is due to oxygen in N‒C‒O bond. When AC is coated on the CN/HU, for CNHU/AC5, a new peak at 530.91 eV due to C = O can be observed [49,50]. These findings suggest that CNHU/AC5 has rich functional groups, including –OH on the g-C3N4 surface and C = O and O = C‒OH groups on the AC surface. The existence of these groups can affect the photoelectricity performance of CNHU/AC5, and thus affect the photocatalysis activity. 3.2 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared samples was evaluated through Cr(VI) reduction under visible-light irradiation, using citric acid as a hole scavenger. It is observed that the adsorption capacity of all samples to Cr(VI) is negligible in the darkness, which may be related to the negative charge of the catalyst and the low dosage. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the photocatalytic activity of CNHU is significantly increased, suggesting that ultrasonic-hydrothermal synthesis can increases the photocatalytic activity. CNHU/ACx demonstrate a higher reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) when AC is coated on the CNHU surface. The first order rate constants(k) for CNHU/ACx (x = 0.5, 2.5, 5, 10) are calculated to be 1.53 × 10–2 min-1, 1.89 × 10–2 min-1, 2.77 × 10–2 min-1 and 1.59 × 10–2 min-1, respectively (Fig. 4b). Notably, CNHU/AC5 demonstrated the highest photocatalytic activity, with rate constants 6.6 times and 2.1 times higher than those of CN (4.22 × 10–3 min-1) and CNHU (1.33 × 10–2 min-1), respectively. Compared to other photocatalysts (Table S3), CNHU/AC5 stands out for its highly effective photocatalytic Cr(VI) removal performance and its metal-free, low-cost composition. Photocatalytic reduction of Cu(II) was further evaluated. As shown in Fig. S4, CNHU/AC5 achieved 57 % Cu(II) reduction within 60 min under visible light irradiation, confirming its efficacy beyond Cr(VI) removal. This capability suggested the catalyst’s potential application in heavy metal recovery. In order to illustrate the promotion of ultrasonic-hydrothermal method on photocatalytic activity, the combination of AC and CN was also prepared by the thermal condensation of AC and dicyandiamide based on the physical mixing method, and it was found to be very poor in activity, as shown in Fig 4c and 4d These finding demonstrate that adding AC to g-C3N4 increases its photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 and hydrothermal treatment can improve the interface between AC and g-C3N4 [51]. The initial pH of a solution can significantly impact the surface chemical characteristics of the photocatalyst as well as the chemical states of Cr(VI). Consequently, the influence of varying initial pH levels on the reduction efficiency of Cr(VI) was investigated. The role of pH was assessed in the context of the photoreduction process of Cr(VI). It can be seen from Fig. S6 that adsorption capacity of Cr(VI) remained less than 3 % across all pH values, indicating negligible electrostatic attraction despite charge variations (Fig. S5). While the initial pH of the solution plays a crucial role in the reduction of Cr(VI) (Fig. 5 a). The reduction efficiency decreases from 93.5 % to 33.2 % when pH value increases from 1.0 to 5. When pH is at 7.0, CNHU/AC5 is almost inactivated. As described in the literatures [52,53], Cr(VI) occurs as HCrO4 - and Cr2O7 2- in acidic solution, and Cr2O4 2- in alkaline solution. Because the catalyst surface is positively charged under acidic circumstances, Cr(VI) can be adsorbed to the g-C3N4 surface via electrostatic attraction. While Cr(VI) cannot be adsorbed on negatively charged samples due to charge repulsion when the catalyst surface is negatively charged under alkaline circumstances, the reduction process does not take place. Obviously, the acidic circumstance is beneficial to the Cr(VI) reduction [54]. The photoreduction path of Cr(VI) is as following: (1) C r 2 O 7 2 − + 14 H + + 6 e − → 2 C r 3 + + 7 H 2 O (2) HCrO 4 − + 7 H + + 3 e − → C r 3 + + 4 H 2 O (3) CrO 4 2 − + 4 H 2 O + 3 e − → Cr ( OH ) 3 + 5 O H − The dosage of the catalyst is a critical parameter influencing the reduction of Cr(VI). As illustrated in Fig. 5b, an increase in the CNHU/AC5 dosage from 10 mg to 40 mg resulted in a marked enhancement in the Cr(VI) reduction rate. However, upon reaching a catalyst dosage of 60 mg, the improvement in Cr(VI) reduction efficiency was minimal. This phenomenon may be attributed to the presence of excess catalysts, which could reflect or scatter photons, thereby impeding the excitation of the catalysts. Scavenger experiments were conducted using established hole scavengers: ethanol (EA), citric acid (CA), and tartaric acid (TA). As shown in Fig. 5c, systems without scavengers exhibited negligible Cr(VI) reduction regardless of illumination. The additon of scavengers significantly enhanced photocatalytic efficiency, with performance increasing in the order EA < CA < TA. This trend correlates with both the density of carboxyl groups and Cr(VI) complexation capacity of the scavenger. Citric acid has three terminal O = C‒OH group and an alpha –OH group, while tartaric acid has two terminal O = C‒OH group and two alpha –OH group. They have stronger hole trapping and more complex Cr(VI) capacity than ethanol. The generation of the Cr(VI)-polycarboxylates complexes is demonstrated prerequisite for the rapid redox conversions of Cr(VI), which is due to that polycarboxylates might facilitate electron transfer to Cr(VI). To determine the practical application, Cr(VI) reduction was evaluated in tap water, river water and deionized water using CNHU/AC5 under visible light (Fig. 5d). The system maintained robust performance in tap and river water,with just a 10 % efficiency loss compared to deinonized water, indicating great environmental adaptation. The marginal inhibition is due to competing ion adsorption and light scattering by suspended particles. Notably, river water outperforms tap water because the dissolved organic matter acts as a natural hole scavenger, accelerating the separation of photo-induced e-/h + pairs. Recycle testing of photocatalytically reduction of Cr(VI) was done to detect the stability of CNHU/AC5. Fig. 6 a illustrates the photocatalytic activity in the cycling runs. Only a small decline in the photocatalytic activity of CNHU/AC5 can be discovered after four times, indicating that CNHU/AC5 has good activity stability. XRD and XPS analysis were utilized to further investigate the mechanism responsible for the photocatalytic activity decline. As shown in Fig. 6b, the major XRD peaks of used CNHU/AC5 and fresh CNHU/AC5 were almost identical, demonstrating that the crystal structure was not affected [55]. Additionally, the Cr 2p XPS peaks centered at 576.87 and 587.05 eV can be attributed to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2 of Cr(Ⅲ) [56], respectively (Fig. 6c). This demonstrates that in the photocatalytic process under light-irradiation, Cr(VI) is reduced to Cr(III), companying with some Cr(III) deposited on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, there are no substantial changes in the peak position of C 1 s, N 1 s and O 1 s spectra, indicating that no new chemical states of C, N and O atoms are induced (Fig. 6d∼f). However, the relative content of O atoms increases from 3.76 % for fresh CNHU/AC5 to 4.76 % for used CNHU/AC5 (Table S4). The discrepancies could be related to the inevitable surface oxidation of g-C3N4 [57]. 3.3 Energy band structure of semiconductor photocatalysts The UV–Vis DRS is recorded to characterize the optical absorption property of all the samples. As shown in Fig. 7 a, hydrothermal reactions exhibit little effect on the improvement of light absorption properties of g-C3N4, but after AC modification, the light absorption properties are significantly improved. This definitely indicated that the spectrum acquired for CNHU/ACx integrated CN and AC optical characteristics. In addition, the concentration of AC in CNHU/AC increased along with the absorption of visible light. The colors of the spectrum change from light yellow to dark cyan with the increase of AC doping, suggesting the increase of its light absorption intensity. However, the enhancement in visible light absorption became less pronounced at higher AC loading, which attributed to light scattering effect caused by AC overlayer [58]. The band gap values of CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 samples are estimated using Kubelka-Munk formula. As can be seen in Fig. 7b, the band gap values (Eg) of CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 are found to be 2.72 eV, 2.72 eV and 2.68 eV. The wavelength threshold remained relatively stable and the band gap of CNHU/AC was almost identical to that of pristine g-C3N4. This phenomenon also demonstrated the non-chemical bond contact between g-C3N4 and AC, in agreement with the XPS analysis [39]. The optical properties and band structure of the as prepared samples were also investigated. As shown in Figure 7c-7e, the positive slopes of the Mott-Shottky plots indicate that CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 are all typical n-type semiconductor. The flat-band potential (Vfb) of the samples is determined to be −1.11 eV, ‒0.91 eV and −1.31 eV vs. Ag/AgCl (Fig. 7c-7e). The normal hydrogen electrode potential is ENHE= EAg/AgCl+ 0.197, and thus the Ef of CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 can be converted to be −0.91 eV, −0.71 eV and −1.11 eV (NHE, pH = 7), respectively. For an n-type semiconductor, the bottom of the conduction band minimum (Ecb) located about 0.1 eV∼0.3 eV lower than Efb, resulting in Ecb of CN, CNHU and AC at ca. −1.11 eV,−0.91 eV and −1.31 eV (NHE, pH = 7). Considering the Eg of CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 is 2.72 and 2.68 eV, the valence band potential (Evb) can be calculated using the equation Evb=Ecb+Eg, resulting in the Evb values of CN, CNHU and AC are 1.61, 1.81 and 1.37 eV. Based on the above calculation results, the specific parameters of CNHU and AC were illustrated intuitively in Fig. 7f. The CB edge location of CNHU/AC5 is 0.4 eV higher than that of the CNHU sample, meaning that CNHU/AC5 has a higher reduction potential for Cr(VI). 3.4 Mechanism of the photocatalytic activity To elucidate the role of AC modification in facilitating photogenerated charge carrier migration, the photoluminescence (PL) spectra, transient photocurrent response, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the fluorescence intensities of CNHU are much lower than that of CN, demonstrating that the one-dimensional nanorod structure may significantly increase the separation of photogenerated carriers. When AC is coated on the CNHU surface, the fluorescence intensity of CNHU/AC5 is further reduced. Moreover, the fluorescence intensity of CNHU/ACs decrease significantly with the increased AC contents (Fig. S7). This finding suggests that AC coating facilitates the separation of photogenerated carriers. Complementary electrochemical measurements corroborate these findings. CNHU/AC5 displays the highest photocurrent intensity (Fig. 8b) and a much smaller radius of Nyquist circle (Fig. 8c), suggesting that the charge separation and transfer efficiency of photogenerated electrons and holes has greatly improved. These finding show that hydrothermal processes and the AC coating can effectively inhibit the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes on CNHU/AC5. This is beneficial to the improvement of photocatalytic activity. The work function serves as a crucial role for analyzing interfacial charge transfer at the interface of CNHU/AC. The work functions(Φ) of AC and CNHU were quantified as 6.59 eV and 5.51 eV, respectively. These values were calculated through the equation: ΔV=Φ-φ, where ΔV corresponds to the distance between inflection points (IP) as illustrated in Fig. 9 (a–b)), and φ represents the fixed electron work function (4.45 eV) of the XPS analyzer [40,59]. A higher Φ value indicates stronger electron retention capacity. The Fermi energy level of CNHU is higher than that of AC. Upon interfacial contact, electrons actively shift from the lower work function of CNHU to the higher work function of AC, resulting in a new equilibrium. The directional transfer designates AC as an effective electron sink, facilitating electron accumulation for surface redox processes. Importantly, optimized CNHU/AC heterojunction formation creates an energy barrier that significantly suppresses charge carrier recombination (e-/h + pairs) within the CNHU matrix. The electron transfer pathway is also supported by density functional theory (DFT) simulations [60,61]. As illustrated in Fig. 9 d, the isosurface level was set to 0.0009 e/Å3 to highlight significant charge redistribution while filtering negligible fluctuations. Distinct electron accumulation (Δρ > 0, blue regions) and depletion (Δρ <0, yellow regions) were observed at the interface. Specifically, electrons accumulated predominantly on the AC side, whereas a marked electron depletion occurred near the g-C3N4 region, indicating a net electron transfer from g-C3N4 to AC. Duo to the unique electron transport and photoelectronic coupling properties of activated carbon, AC modification has been domonstrated to significantly enhance the photoelectric performance of g-C3N4 [29,62,63]. The functional groups in CNHU/AC, including –OH, C = O and O = C OH, play diverse roles in Cr(VI) reduction. Surface hydroxyl(-OH) groups on g-C3N4 extend the 2D conjugate electron system and achieve local spatial charge separation [64], while C = O and O = C‒OH groups on AC act as electron traps, analogous to precious metal co-catalysts on semiconductor surface [65]. Thus, by trapping photoinduced electrons, they can further minimize the potential of recombination of photogenerated e-–h + pairs in g-C3N4 by capturing photoinduced electrons, favoring the enhancement of photocatalytic process. On the other hand, the creation of a heterojunction between AC and CNHU has changed the electron transfer path, increasing photocatalytic activity. However, the photocatalytic activity of CNHU/ACx doesn’t continuously enhanced with higher AC dosage. This could be owing to AC’s significant light absorption and scattering capabilities, excessive loading of AC would prevent visible light from reaching the interface of AC and CN, which might be the most active sites. To investigate the free radicals during the Cr(VI) reduction process in the CNHU/AC5 reaction system, ESR measurements were carried out. It can be seen from Fig. 10 a and b that no signals is observed in the dark condition, while strong characteristic signals of both DMPO-•OH (1:2:2:1) and DMPO-•O2 ‒ (1:1:1:1) are detected over CNHU/AC5 under visible-light irradiation. It is noteworthy that signal of •OH radical can be found over CNHU and CNHU/AC5, but no •OH signals detected over CN under the same identical conditions. Moreover, CNHU/AC5 displays much stronger signal of DMPO-•O2 ‒ compared with CNHU and CN. According to the energy band structure, the potentials of OH/•OH were positive than the VB of CN and CNHU/AC5, which was unable to react with OH‒ for generating •OH. Thus, it can be inferred that the formation of •OH and •O2 ‒ radicals in the system may mainly derive from the capacity of a nontrivial self-photocatalytic activity of AC which depend on the surface chemistry of the activated carbons [63,66]. The photogenerated electron and hole pairs first form on the surface of activated carbon after irradiation (Reaction (4)). The positive holes can form •OH by capturing water molecules. (Reaction (5)). The electrons, on the other hand, react with the adsorbed oxygen molecule to produce superoxide anion (Reaction (6)), which can combine with the water molecule to produce oxidizing radical species (Reactions (7)–(8)). Based on the findings, it can be inferred that AC coating has an effect on g-C3N4 that involves not only physicochemical changes but also the promotion of active radical production. (4) AC + hv → h + + e − (5) h + + H 2 O → • OH + H + (6) e − + O 2 → • O 2 − (7) • O 2 − + H + → • H O 2 (8) 2 • H O 2 → O 2 + H 2 O 2 → O 2 + 2 • OH Subsequently, the concentration of generated ROS were quantified(Fig. 10c). When CN, CNHU and CNHU/AC5 were used as catalysts, the •OH concentrations reached 0.12 μM, 0.13 μM, and 0.16 μM respectively, while •O2 – concentration was 20.44 μM, 73.89 μM and 107.22 μM. The CNHU/AC system demonstrated significantly higher •OH and •O2 − concentrations than CNHU and CN, indicating its superior and stable ROS generation capacity. Furthermore, the concentration of •OH and •O2 − exhibited strong positive correlations with Cr(VI) reduction rates (Fig. 10d-e), confirming that AC coating effectively facilitates the charge carrier separation and oxygen activation. To verify the roles of active species in the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI), trapping experiments were performed, as shown in Fig. 10f. Generally, tert‑butanol (TBA) and sodium persulfate (Na2S2O8) were used as scavengers, which can capture •OH and e‒, respectively. Furthermore, nitrogen gas was supplied to avoid the production of •O2 ‒ by removing dissolved oxygen gas from the reaction solution. The efficiency reduction of Cr(VI) is about 51.7 % suppression as the photogenerated electrons is captured by the adding of Na2S2O8, demonstrating that the photogenerated electrons play the dominant role for Cr(VI) reduction which follows the one-electron reaction process (Reactions (9)). When TBA is induced into the reaction system, the Cr(VI) reduction efficiency decreases about 35.9 %, indicating that the formed •OH radical could favor the separation of electrons and holes and further promote the Cr(VI) reduction activity. Additionally, as shown in Reactions (10), the •OH formation might have a minor effect on the oxidation of Cr(V) back to Cr(VI) [67]. Moreover, citric acid functions as both a hole scavenger and Cr(VI) complexation agent. It actively consumes photogenerated holes and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) through oxidation reactions, thereby suppressing the formation of Cr(V) intermediates. Concurrently, citric acid stabilizes Cr(III) products via chelation to inhibit re-oxidation while facilitating electron transfer to Cr(VI) (Reaction 11). The removal efficiency of Cr(VI) slightly increases when the solution is bubbling with N2, but it decreases significantly when O2 is introduced into the solution. These findings indicate that Cr(VI) is directly reduced by the photogenerated electrons over CNHU/AC5, but O2 in the solution completes Cr(VI) for the photogenerated electrons, blocking Cr(VI) reduction [54,68]. (9) Cr ( VI ) → e − Cr ( V ) → e − Cr ( IV ) → e − Cr ( III ) (10) Cr ( V ) + h + / • OH → Cr ( VI ) + O H − (11) Cit + h + / • OH → Oxidatioin products Given the above analysis, the enhanced Cr(VI) reduction for the CNHU/AC catalyst is proposed, as shown in Fig. 11 . First, AC modification simultaneously enhanced visible-light absorption and elevates the conduction band potential (−1.32 V vs. NHE), thereby enhancing the system’s reductive capacity. Second, the CNHU/AC heterojunction drives interfacial electron transfer toward AC’s electron-trapping functional groups (C = O/O = C OH), while the 1D nanorod morphology further suppressing e-/h +recombination. Third, citric acid acts as a reactant as well as a co-catalyst in this system, reducing electron and hole recombination, inhibiting Cr(Ⅲ) re-oxidation and facilitating electron transfer to Cr(VI). These three synergistic effects collectively account for the superior photocatalytic performance of CNHU/AC5. 4 Conclusion In summary, AC coated g-C3N4 nanorod (CNHU/AC) is successfully fabricated by hydrothermal method assisted with ultrasonic. The unique interfacial structure and surface functional groups of CNHU/AC synergistically promote charge separation and accelerate surface electron transfer, while the AC coating simultaneously improve the visible-light absorption capacity of CN. Compared with bulk g-C3N4, the as-prepared CNHU/AC composite shows much better photocatalytic activity in reduction of Cr(VI) under visible light. Based on the trapping experiment, the photogenerated electrons play the most important role in the reductive system. Furthermore, Cr (VI) photoreduction was clearly inhibited by O2 exits. This work might offer new ideas for creating high-efficiency AC modified g-C3N4 catalyst with significant potential for Cr(VI)-containing wastewater. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, we developed a one-dimensional activated carbon (AC) coated graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) hybrid nanorods (CNHU/AC) synthesized via an ultrasonic-hydrothermal method. The dual modulation of ultrasonic cavitation and hydrothermal confinement enables simultaneous morphology engineering (1D nanorod formation) and inerfacial microstructure optimization, endowing CNHU/AC with exceptional photoelectron transfer properties. Comparative studies with pristine g-C3N4 and hydrothermally modified CNHU without AC addition reveal that the optimal AC loading (CNHU/AC5) achieves remarkable Cr(VI) photoreduction under visible light, exhibiting rate constants 6.6 times and 2.1 times higher than those of g-C3N4 and CNHU, respectively. This enhancement originates from synergistic effects: (1) AC’s photosensitization broadens light absorption while its coating establishes intimate interfacial contact for accelerated charge transfer; (2) The 1D architecture directs axial elctron transport, coupled with surface C = O/O = C OH groups acting as electron traps; (3) Citric acid functions as both hole scavenger and Cr(VI) complexation agent to lower reduction barriers. This study establishes a paradigm for designing carbon-coupled heterostructures for the sustainable heavy metal remediation.
coredata.dc:title: Work-function-tailored electron transfer in 1D g-C₃N₄-HU/AC nanorods: ultrasonic-hydrothermal microstructure crafting for heavy metal ions photoreduction
